model.name: Shanghai
model.description: One hundred-plus years ago, Shanghai was the chicest city in the world, a mashup of Las Vegas, New York, and Paris, with dozens of nationalities living within its borders. These days, the place once known as "The Paris of the East" has reclaimed its crown, with China's most exciting and innovative restaurants, galleries, shopping, and, yes, people of all sorts spread along the two banks of the Huangpu River. Happily, the city's not all 21st-century glitz and luxury brand-name boutiques; pockets of its colonial past are being restored and preserved, which means that even in this nonstop megapolis, you can still find the spirit of the old city.
model.seoName: Things To Do In Shanghai – Attractions & Travel Guide
model.seoDescription: Plan your trip to Los Angeles with Condé Nast Traveler’s guide to the best hotels, restaurants, and things to do.
model.socialName: Shanghai City Guide: Where to Eat, Stay, and Play

fields.caption:
"Only spending one week in China," says [Mei Zhang, of WildChina](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists/mei-zhang). "I think in order to really experience China—and to properly get over the jet lag—it takes at least ten days. Our most popular trip introduces newcomers to Beijing, Xi’an, Shanghai, and then has a splash of action in rural Yunnan. We can theoretically do this trip in eight days, but it is much more relaxing to enjoy it over two weeks."

featuredEats.name: Si Ji Xuan

address.street: 500 Weihai Rd., Four Seasons Hotel Shanghai, 2nd Floor

featuredEats.description: In Shanghai, just as there is no shame in eating in chain restaurants or shopping malls, or even chain restaurants in shopping malls, so too there is no stigma attached to hotel dining. Opt for a mix of traditional Cantonese and Shanghainese dishes and the restaurant's specialty, a plate of wok-fried scallops and tender abalone mushrooms. The place offers a very reasonable dim sum brunch over the weekend. Be sure to book ahead.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Order the restaurant's specialty, a plate of wok-fried scallops and tender abalone mushrooms.

featuredEats.name: Mei Long Zhen
featuredEats.description: Established in 1938, this restaurant takes its name from the Ming Dynasty emperor, Zhengde, who was rumoured to visit the Meilongzhen village incognito. Since its inception, it continues to be a well-frequented venue and was historically a meeting place for Shanghai's cultural elite. Outfitted in mahogany, marble, and intricate woodwork, it's like taking a walk down memory lane to an older Shanghai. Food is a fusion of Shanghainese, Sichuanese, and Yangzhou flavours. Specializing in Sichuanese, Yangzhou, and "eventually" Shanghainese cuisine respectively, over time its master chefs merged to form a special menu of fusion tastes, long before fusion was even close to cool. A huge venue with seating for 600 and total of seven dining halls, Mei Long Zhen houses some of the most elaborate décor around (some's a bit over the top, but embrace the kitsch) and a price range to justify any budget from modest RMB 18 dishes to the impress-the-in-laws-worthy RMB 1,500 offerings. Service with a smile? Yes! One of the list's friendlier places, including the alley guard.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Established in 1938, Mei Long Zhen was historically a meeting place for Shanghai's cultural elite.

featuredEats.name: Uo Kura

address.street: 507 Fuxing Zhong Rd., Sinan Mansions, Block 2, 3rd Floor

featuredEats.description: Restaurateur Howard Ing has brought together a three-Michelin-star chef and a sushi master to create the ultimate Osaka-style kaiseki restaurant in Shanghai's Sinan Mansions development. Admirer Max Levy describes the menu, chef Hideaki Matsuo's domain, as "spot-on," with a "succulent poached oyster floating in dashi that's the pure essence of the sea." But, Levy says, "the real magic is at the beautiful sushi bar, where you can have the best sushi outside Kansai." It doesn't hurt that the restaurant has views of the former residence of Sun Yat-Sen and Fu Xing park.
featuredEats.shortDescription: This Osaka-style kaiseki restaurant has views Fu Xing Park and Sun Yat-Sen's former residence.

featuredEats.name: Yin Par Le Garcon Chinois
featuredEats.description: Yin, from the Jinjiang Hotel, which has now merged with Le Garçon Chinois, has still retained its Old-World interior design despite having moved into a less charming arcade building, and is neighbors to a kitsch Arabian Nights-themed restaurant. Modern paintings hang on the walls and there is a little stage where a jazz guitarist or pianist sometimes plays. There are lithe waitresses dressed in samfoos. The menu is a combination of Shanghainese and Sichuanese food, and is light on the oil and sweetness. Almost every evening, you will find Japanese owner, Takashi, seated at his private sushi bar adjacent to the dining area sipping a robust red wine with his mother who formally greets each patron swathed in her traditional kimono.
featuredEats.shortDescription: The menu is a combination of Shanghainese and Sichuanese food, and is light on oil and sweetness.

featuredStays.name: Park Hyatt Shanghai
featuredStays.description: Asia's second most vertiginous hotel is on floors 79 through 93 of the Shanghai World Financial Center, in the Pudong district. All 174 generous-sized rooms provide jaw-dropping Shanghai or Pudong panoramas, cloud-like bedding, and cashmere-soft carpets, and come with extra touches such as diagrams to explain the light switches and even motion sensor-operated heated commode seats. Owner Minoru Mori, who built Toyko's groundbreaking Roppongi Hills complex, influenced the art here, which includes hundreds of kitsch ceramics by Liu Jianhua hanging from the ceiling of 100 Century Avenue, a highly recommended showplace restaurant on the ninety-first floor. Two additional restaurants and 12 elegant private dining rooms offer everything from comfort food such as soup dumplings to formal banquets.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Asia's second most vertiginous hotel is on floors 79 through 93 of the Shanghai World Financial Center.

featuredStays.name: PuLi Hotel and Spa
featuredStays.description: A glass tower with fabulous city views and friendly service, the PuLi provides sanctuary from the chaos of downtown Shanghai, despite its construction-heavy JingAn district location. The look—quite like modern Shanghai—is sleek and contemporary, with subtle Chinese details: The striking 105-foot lobby doubles as the Long Bar, with glossy floors, shades-of-gray naive portraits by native artist Li Jing Bin, vases, and floor-to-ceiling light panels, and has an outdoor terrace. The 229 stylish rooms and suites are large—starting at 484 square feet—and well laid-out. The open-plan studio room has a wood-lattice screen separating the entrance hall from the main bedroom/living room, furnished with a sofa; a glass panel with Chinese silk divides the bedroom from the bathroom, which has a tub backed by a limestone-tiled wall in addition to a walk-in shower. The free minibar (including wine and mineral water in Club Floor rooms) is a welcome perk. An international crowd of creative types gather for dinner at JingAn restaurant, which is helmed by Kiwi chef Dane Clouston, formerly of Hong Kong’s JIA hotel. There’s a stunning indoor infinity pool looking out over JingAn Park, and a small Anantara spa, which has good, if not superlative, treatments.
featuredStays.shortDescription: The look of this 229 room hotel is sleek and contemporary, with subtle Chinese details.

featuredStays.name: The Peninsula Shanghai
featuredStays.description: The brand's third hotel in China is, as custom dictates in this megalopolis of scaffolding and swinging cranes, a new-build grown from the rubble of a demolished structure, amid the Bund's historic sweep of colonial edifices. The opulent interior plays on the Art Deco style of the hotel's neighbors: The grand lobby, where breakfast and afternoon tea are taken, has soaring pillars and chandeliers, and acres of gleaming-black marble line the hallways. Drinking and dining options range from the low-lit Compass bar, with velvet armchairs and a pianist, to the elaborate four-room Salon de Ning, which mixes animal prints, leather, and Deco portraits; other amenities include an 82-foot pool and an ESPA spa. The 235 rooms are comfortable and compact with expected five-star elements: a calming taupe-and-blue color scheme, leather headboards, black lacquer cabinets, and, best of all, a capacious walk-in dressing room with cornflower silk walls. They're tricked out with intuitive gadgetry as well - a Nepresso machine, a TV in the bathroom, and a cupboard that magically dispatches clothes to the laundry - and international calls and Wi-Fi are complimentary. Service was not quite up to The Peninsula chain's high standards: A misunderstanding over luggage resulted in repeated phone calls and interruptions. And despite the iconic location, one can feel hermetically sealed off from Shanghai in this glossy, predominantly business hotel. Still, five-star cosseting - which includes free Rolls-Royce or BMW airport transfers - has its benefits.
featuredStays.shortDescription: The opulent interior plays on the Art Deco style of the hotel's neighbors in the Bund district.

featuredStays.name: Four Seasons Hotel Shanghai at Pudong
featuredStays.description: A 187-room high-rise in the central business district, within strolling distance of the sky-high Jinmao Tower and Shanghai World Financial Center.
featuredStays.shortDescription: A 187-room hotel is in a high-rise in Shanghai's central business district.

shop.hed: Michael Kors’s 5-Step Guide to Conquering Shanghai
shop.dek: Michael Kors is the latest designer to open up shop in Shanghai, the world’s new shopping capital. We asked him for his tips on seeing the city in style.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/5473b235cbbd2620680dcfa4]|||
Kors and co. cutting the tape at the grand opening of his new Shanghai store.
|||  


##Stop by the Flagship
The exterior of the [Michael Kors store in Shanghai](http://cntraveler.com/shops/shanghai/michael-kors-shanghai) (currently the largest Kors outpost in the world) was inspired by a sequined gown. It’s located in Shanghai's [Jing'an Kerry Centre](http://www.jingankerrycentre.com/), a luxury shopping center spread over three towers on Nanjing Road West. (*1618 Nanjing Road West, Jing’an District, Shanghai, +86 21 6288 7128*)


##Fly Direct 
 When traveling to Shanghai, Kors always flies direct. Travel essentials include Beats by Dre Headphones, an iPad, La Mer lip balm, and a cozy cashmere sweater.

##Go Modern 
Upon arrival, Kors heads to either the [Peninsula Hotel](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/marana/peninsula-shanghai) or [Park Hyatt](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/china/shanghai/park-hyatt-shanghai*). He loves the former for its Art Deco luxe, and the latter for its dazzling views over the Bund (it’s the tallest hotel in the world). First stop at the Park Hyatt? A swim in its pool on the 85th floor.

##Find the Cashmere and Silk 
Kors doesn’t leave Shanghai without stocking up on cashmere wraps from Ruyee Life Gallery on the Bund (*1 Lane 8, Zhong Shan Dong Yi Lu, Shanghai, +86 21 6445 8218*) and then heads to Shiatzy Chen for silk and cotton pieces (*32 The Bund, Zhongshan Dong Yi Road, Shanghai, +86 21 6321 9155, shiatzychen.com*).

##Don't Leave without tasting Dim Sum
No trip to China is complete without a dim sum stop. Kors recommends the Kerry Center outpost of popular dumpling restaurant Din Tai Fung, whose signature dumpling is, of course, the traditional soup dumpling (*2F, Yu Fashion Garden, 168 Fangbang M. Road, Shanghai, +86  21 6334 1008, dintaifungusa.com*).

fields.name: Avery Matera
fields.shortBio: Avery Matera is a fashion and style writer born and bred in NYC.
fields.bio: Born and bred in NYC, Avery Matera is a fashion and style writer. In addition to her undying passion for this perfect concrete jungle, she lives for the beaches of Cape Cod and ski slopes of Tahoe. A striped shirt aficionado and lover of classic pajama sets, she will forever be on the hunt for the next eclectic bracelet to add to her collection.

shop.dek: Condé Nast Traveler Global Affairs Editor Dorinda Elliott shares her favorite Shanghai shops.
shop.seoDescription: _Condé Nast Traveler_ Global Affairs Editor Dorinda Elliott shares her picks for Shanghai's best shops
shop.socialDescription: _Condé Nast Traveler_ Global Affairs Editor Dorinda Elliott shares her picks for Shanghai's best shops
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9baa06dec627b149ccb86]||||||

[#image: /photos/53d9baa0dcd5888e145974d9]||||||

[#image: /photos/53d9baa0dcd5888e145974d7]|||A stroll along The Bund is a must-do when visiting Shanghai|||






**[MADAME MAO'S DOWRY](http://madamemaosdowry.com)** This is a great place for Communist-era paraphernalia, from 1960s enameled platters emblazoned with Socialist slogans to old awards given to good students. The one-of-a-kind clothing designs, from Mao-style jackets to baggy silk trousers, are quirky and chic (No. 207, Fumin Lu; 86-21-540-33551).








**DONGTAI ROAD ANTIQUE MARKET** Most of the “antiques” here are fake, but you can occasionally find some fun old Shanghai paraphernalia. I recently bought a 1930s map of Shanghai, which I swear is real. It’s fun to wander through and haggle with the salesmen (Dongtai Rd.; 86-21-5582-5254).




**MOGANSHAN DISTRICT** I always head straight for the Moganshan art district, in former warehouse buildings near Suzhou Creek, to check out what’s new in the art scene. Lorenz Helbling’s ShanghART, in a large, whitewashed space, is one of the most respected galleries (50 Moganshan Road, Bldg. 16; 86-21-6359-3923).







**TAIKANG ROAD** This area in the French Concession has become an arts and crafts shopping mecca, with tons of fun little boutiques selling one-of-a-kind clothing designs, jewelry, yak-wool scarves, and colorful cloth shoes, often with a Chinese accent. This is a great place to buy gifts.








**[URBAN TRIBE](http://urbantribe.cn/style1en.html)** This is a super-cool Shanghai label. Its baggy pants, blouses, and jackets, made in natural fabrics, take inspiration from China’s ethnic minorities. Check out the tea garden in the back (133 West Fuxing Lu; 86-21-6433-5366).











Image Courtesy of Madame Mao's Dowry

shop.hed: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
shop.dek: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here's where to go.
shop.seoTitle: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
shop.seoDescription: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here’s where to go.
shop.socialTitle: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
shop.socialDescription: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here’s where to go.

items.caption: The must-go marketplace? Yu Yuan Gardens and Bazaar. Although a bit touristy, it's still worth it for its selection of everything from scarves and clothing to jewelry and knick-knacks (218 Anren St, Huangpu, Shanghai, +86 21 6326 0830).

Almost 6 miles from end to end, Nanjing Road tends to be separated into two sections: Nanjing East Road and Nanjing West Road. Here you’ll find small shops and markets selling original jewelry, accessories, and food, as well as storefronts of larger more commonly known brands. From here, you can also visit Reel Mall, on Nanjing West Road, which is full of high end stores from both Chinese and International designers.

Art collectors shouldn’t miss the M50 Art Hub on Morgan Shan Road. The artist-run complex, which houses galleries such as ShanghART (50 Moganshan Rd, Putuo, Shanghai, +86 21 6359 3923, [shanghartgallery.com](http://shanghartgallery.com)) and Art Scene China (2/F, Bldg #4, 50 Morganshan Road, Shanghai, +86 21 6277 4940, [artscenechina.com](http://artscenechina.com)), is worth a visit for anyone interested in China’s contemporary art scene.

Shanghai is well known for its custom tailoring and designs. At W.W. Chan & Sons Tailor Ltd., you’ll be able to construct an entire wardrobe from scratch. You can bring in photographs of styles you’re interested in, and then choose your own fabrics from the voluminous collection of sample books ( 528, 5/F, West Tower Shanghai Centre, 1376 Nanjing Road West, +86 21 6289 8682, [wwchan.com](http://wwchan.com)).

Pearls are a local specialty, and Shanghai Pearl City stocks pearls in every size, shape, and hue. It can be a bit overwhelming, so you need to know what you’re looking for, but their prices are quite competitive so it’s well worth the trip (3721 Hongmei Lu, Shanghai, +86 21 6262 3851).

Founded in 2010, M.R.K.T. is full of architecture-inspired bags and accessories in clean, geometric concepts, all made of everything from vegan leather to felt, and produced in a rainbow of colors (741 Julu Rd, Jing'an, Shanghai, +86 21 5403 0791, [mrktstore.com](http://mrktstore.com)).

contributorsAuthor.shortBio: Sydney-born, Shanghai-based travel writer reporting on all things chic in China
contributorsAuthor.bio: Sydney-born Amy Fabris-Shi toured the world as a professional ballerina but now takes a rather more leisurely approach to travel as a globetrotting writer and co-founder of boutique content consultancy, [Scribes of the Orient](www.scibesoftheorient.com). Based in Shanghai for the past decade, she writes about all things chic in China and beyond for publications including *Elite Traveler*, *Conde Nast Traveller* and *MO Magazine*.

featuredPlays.name: ShanghART Gallery
featuredPlays.description: As China's contemporary art scene continues to heat up, one of the best places to catch a glimpse (or even buy) is the growing cluster of galleries housed in warehouses in the Moganshan Lu creative district. Once known mostly for its polluted river, Moganshan Lu began to attract local artists in the late 1990s with its enormous loft spaces and cheap rent. Start at the city's first contemporary art space, ShanghART Gallery, which focuses on local artists and, to a lesser degree, the rest of China. Check out other pioneering galleries—the massive Art Scene Warehouse often hosts group exhibits that offer a good overview, while Eastlink showcases more risqué work by art stars Ai Weiwei and the Gao Brothers.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: The city's first contemporary art space focuses on local and national artists.

featuredPlays.name: Duolun Cultural Street

address.street: Duolun Rd. (near Sichuan Bei Rd.), Hongkou Qu

featuredPlays.description: This cultural street was once home to many aspiring writers from the early 20th century, some of whom comprise the League of Leftist Writers. It has managed to retain its dusty charm despite recent restoration. Today it is lined with teahouses, antique shops, cafés, and galleries that blend in effortlessly.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: This historic street is lined with teahouses, antique shops, cafés, and galleries.

featuredPlays.name: Shanghai Museum
featuredPlays.description: With 120,000 works of art on view, this premier collection of Chinese artifacts warrants at least half a day to browse the ten galleries of calligraphy, jade, bronze, ceramics, and sculptures—not to mention furniture from the Ming and Qing dynasties, paintings, coins, and other historical treasures. The audio tours are worthwhile, and written descriptions of the relics are also offered in English. Take a break in the museum's tearoom, and hit the bookshop for souvenirs.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: This premier collection of Chinese artifacts has 120,000 works of art on view.

featuredPlays.name: Ohel Moshe Synagogue
featuredPlays.description: During the 1930s and 40s, more than 10,000 Jews fleeing Nazi persecution landed in Shanghai, which offered refuge to "stateless individuals." Herded by occupying Japanese soldiers into the Hongkou district's narrow houses, they patiently waited out the war years, many in greatly reduced circumstances. Built in 1927, the Ohel Moshe Synagogue now houses the Jewish Refugee Museum, which has two permanent exhibits with artifacts and personal testimonies from the time the area in Hongkou was a Jewish ghetto, including an exhibition space with more general shows about Judaism. Though little remains of the rest of the former Jewish ghetto, you can explore its crumbling remnants in an informative tour led by Israeli journalist Dvir Bar-Gal.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Built in 1927, the Ohel Moshe Synagogue houses the Jewish Refugee Museum.

items.dek: Whampoa Club occupies prime waterfront space above a stack of designer boutiques on The Bund.
Jason Atherton's low-key restaurant serves up bite-sized morsels and well-crafted cocktails.
It's so hard to get a table here that the hours have been extended to accommodate the throng.
This popular local joint has recently undergone a facelift that is reminiscent of European kitsch.
The L-shaped terrace on the seventh floor of Three on Bund affords stunning views of the river.
This place serves modern Shanghai cuisine with a touch of Cantonese.

items.dek: Xintiandi's cobblestone streets comprise a preserved neighborhood-turned-outdoor mall.
This famous market seems to have all of Shanghai's tailors and seamstresses under one roof.
The classiest plaza east of the Huangpu River has the usual glitzy suspects like Hermès and Prada.
Apart from flogging high-end mens and womenswear, this space is a lifestyle-experience in itself.
A thrift shop for Communist-era paraphernalia like 1960s platters emblazoned with Socialist slogans.
This socially responsible label creates stylish-and-sustainable accessories spun from yak down.

cheatSheet.dek: This former French territory is known for its distinct architecture and tree-lined boulevards.

items.dek: This arts and crafts shopping mecca has tons of fun little boutiques.
A plush 32-room boutique residence in a 1930s manor built by a notorious Shanghai mob boss.
An intimate restaurant in a 1930s building with scattered Chinese antiques and Art Deco furnishings.
Temper the menu's peppery Sichuan heat with the house specialty: cooling basil drop martinis.
This stylish tea emporium sells a vast range of Chinese, Asian, and New World teas.

eat.hed: The One Dish To Eat in Shanghai
eat.dek: Paul Pairet, the chef behind the buzzy high-concept Shanghai restaurant Ultraviolet on his favorite dish-including where and how to eat it.
eat.seoTitle: The One Dish To Eat in Shanghai
eat.seoDescription: Paul Pairet, the chef behind the buzzy high-concept Shanghai restaurant Ultraviolet on his favorite dish-including where and how to eat it.
eat.socialTitle: The One Dish To Eat in Shanghai
eat.socialDescription: Paul Pairet, the chef behind the buzzy high-concept Shanghai restaurant Ultraviolet on his favorite dish-including where and how to eat it.
eat.body:
[#image: /photos/549480d31d0dfc7664103ac6]||||||





__You can't leave Shanghai without eating…__

Xiao long bao (Chinese soup dumplings). “This may not be the most surprising recommendation to someone who lives in Shanghai,” says Pairet, “but there’s a reason these dumplings are the city’s signature dish. I, and most people I know, crave them constantly.” There are many different schools of thought about what makes xiao long bao so addictive but, Pairet says, the difference between an average bowl and a melt-in-your-mouth one comes down to three things. First, the wonton wrapper must be thin enough to give the dumpling a satisfyingly explosive bite but also strong enough to withstand the piping hot soup it contains. Second, the stuffing, usually a seasoned mixture of pork and gelatin, must be fatty enough to melt in your mouth. And third, the soup must be rich with flavor.

__How to eat it:__ “I don’t know why, but xiao long bao are always burning, burning hot,” Pairet warns. The traditional solution is to break open the top of each dumpling and let it breathe before dipping it in vinegar then eating it. 

__Where to eat it:__ While there are many higher-end options in Shanghai, Pairet recommends Crystal Jade. The restaurant’s neighborhood, Xintiandi, is well-touristed, and it’s part of a local Cantonese chain. But of all Shanghai’s dumpling spots, Crystal Jade wins—consistently--in each of the three categories (wonton, stuffing, and soup). 

__The science:__ Food writer Christopher St. Cavish, Pairet’s former sous chef at Ultraviolet, is currently working on the final stages of his “Shanghai Soup Dumpling Index”—an attempt to create an objective list of the 20 best xiao long bao restaurants in the city. St. Cavish went to extreme lengths, including measuring wrapper thickness with calipers, to determine which eateries would place on his list. And while the results aren’t yet in, the popular dumpling restaurant Jia Jia Tangbao has previously topped the writer’s list of xiao long bao haunts.

fields.name: Alice Newell-Hanson
fields.shortBio: Alice Newell-Hanson is an assistant editor at Condé Nast Traveler.

eat.dek: Food writer and chef Christopher St Cavish shares his top picks for Chinese specialties and dining options in Shanghai.
eat.hed: A Chef's Guide to Shanghai Cuisine

items.title: Jia Jia Dumplings
items.caption: Xiao long bao, or “little steamer buns," are Shanghai’s calling card. Also known as soup dumplings, the trick here is that the soup is on the inside. A hundred years after their invention in Nanxiang village, the debate rages on about the merits of a thin skin, the porkiness of the filling, and the time elapsed between being made and eating. These, from Jia Jia Tangbao, win high marks in all categories.

items.title: Jia Jia Steam Girls
items.caption: Although xiao long bao are ubiquitous in Shanghai, small venues that make and steam them to order are not. At Jia Jia Tangbao, a crew of young women (said to be chosen for their nimble fingers, essential in handling the delicate dumplings) fill and wrap the dumplings to order and then must brave the steam to retrieve them several minutes later.

items.title: Yangcheng Lake crabs
items.caption: Crab connoisseurs may already know about Shanghai’s hairy crabs, so-called for a matted flop on their claws and fine golden hairs on their legs. True aficionados, however, head straight to Yangcheng Lake an hour away to pick out their crabs themselves. The show up sometime later trussed, steamed, and ready to dip in mellow brown vinegar.

items.title: Zongzi, wrapped
items.caption: In early summer, these bamboo-leaf wrapped parcels, known as zongzi, start appearing en masse in anticipation of the Dragon Boat Festival. The story goes that after an ancient poet-scholar drowned in a lake, the locals threw rice into the waters to distract the fish.

items.title: Zongzi, unwrapped
items.caption: These days, the locals are much more practical. Instead of drowning perfectly good rice, they season it with soy sauce, push a piece of red-braised pork or a salted egg yolk in the center, and wrap it in bamboo or reed leaves to be steamed—a win for the living. These particular zongzi are the work of Chubby Feng, a suburban Shanghai farmer-turned-zongzi mogul.

items.title: Sheng Jian Bao
items.caption: These shallow-fried dumplings are sheng jian bao, the masculine answer to the feminine xiao long bao. Their thicker wrappers hold a similar pork broth inside, but instead of a gentle steam, they go for a golden crisping in these large, iron pans and a sprinkling of sesame seeds and chopped spring onions. These are only found in Shanghai.

items.title: Hot Pot, Yi Pin Ju
items.caption: Although Shanghainese may position themselves in public as much more sophisticated than those Beijing northerners, they’re not above borrowing their hot pot technique in private. Expensive cars line up outside of hole-in-the-wall Yi Pin Ju, smack in downtown, for its hand-cut Mongolian lamb, which gets swished around the coal-fired brass pot and then dunked in a sauce of sesame paste, coriander, and soy sauce or vinegar.

items.title: Liangfen, Yu Xin
items.caption: Sichuan’s fiery cuisine has spread across China in the last decade, and it's extremely popular in Shanghai. Yu Xin Chuan Cai, a chain that originated in Chongqing and cooks as if it never left, is one of the best. Here, the chuanbei liangfen, a cool noodle made from beans, slathered in a spicy, garlicky, and deep savory chili sauce.

items.title: Night Market, Old Town
items.caption: Scenes like this nighttime, al fresco kitchen are disappearing in Shanghai but can still be found on a number of streets in Nanshi, the Old Town of dense, low-rise buildings and lively alleys that is under threat from the march of the skyscrapers.  Even at 3 a.m., as this photo shows, these quick and dirty stir-fry joints do a brisk trade.

items.title: North Korean
items.caption: For something a bit different, try one of Shanghai’s several North Korean restaurants. The NK government-owned chain [Pyongyang Okryu](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/02/north-korean-restaurant-amsterdam-europe-pyongyang) serves up a song and dance along with its banchan and grilled short ribs, complete with North Korean waitresses in traditional dress playing guitars and drums, or belting out folk ballads.

eat.body:
## The Streets of Heavenly Dumplings

## Where does a culinary star go when he wants knockout Chinese food? To the bustling back lanes of Shanghai. [Emily Prager](http://www.cntraveler.com/contributors/emily-prager) walks, talks, and tastes with Jean-Georges Vongerichten
[#image: /photos/53daaf34dcd5888e145c5428]|||No dilly-dallying at Nanxiang Dumpling House.|||

If you walk down Xiangyang Road in Shanghai's French Concession neighborhood, past the ballroom dancers in Xiangyang Park—past the vegetable stand with its Chinese-red tomatoes and its round, dark-green watermelons, past the duck and duck-parts store—you will come to a crossroads that might look rather ordinary at first. Shabby storefronts with streaky windows, tradesmen smoking on the sidewalks, dim cramped rooms with cheap plastic tables and stools spilling out onto the street—all are emblematic of an indistinct kind of Shanghai street, one quickly traversed and barely registered. But before ten in the morning, at lunchtime, and around 6 p.m., this area suddenly surges to life, for Xiangyang Road is one of the city's food streets—and not just any food street but the one at which Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the illustrious chef and restaurateur, must eat when he visits.

Food streets are an institution in Shanghai, where I live, something that is discussed in detail, with attention paid to which is best for what. Streets follow the city plan that the Shanghainese, like the French, love best—clustering—so you might come upon a street entirely of shoe stores or traditional dressmakers or, my personal favorite, devoted only to maternity, with mother-to-be clothes, baby goods, and a maternity hospital with floor-to-ceiling windows through which you can see newborns in circular tanks of water swimming in tiny inner tubes. So the food streets house only restaurants, food vendors of different types, waiters, delivery boys, and, of course, great chefs, which is most assuredly why Jean-Georges feels so comfortable there.

 On a recent morning, as I hurried along to meet Jean-Georges, I was drawn to thinking about the difference between the austere little food street and the coppery-lit elegance that is Jean-Georges's eponymous establishment in Shanghai. Those burgundy-leather banquettes, the burled wood shimmering in the warm light, the serene room with the crystal-clear windows looking out on the Huangpu River, the perfectly prepared food with its sublimely tasteful presentation and finely balanced tastes, the flawless service, all seemed a far cry from the dogged earthiness of the streets. Except for one thing that I could see even from afar: All the chefs were wearing white.


[#image: /photos/53ea88cc976f8f2d44d528fb]||||||

I hadn't quite realized the real purpose of these outfits until I saw Jean-Georges wearing one. They have a slight Asian-scholar feel, with their high collars and their buttons on one side of the chest, as well as a touch of nuclear-containment-facility worker, doctor on grand rounds, sailor in dress uniform, and priest in a cassock (in the long apron that flaps as one walks). Jean-Georges changes into these whites immediately upon arriving at his restaurant. He does not enter the kitchen before casting off his street clothes as if shedding one rather normal persona and quickly assuming a slightly eccentric other. Jean-Georges is, after all, not just a cook but an alchemist in the science of human taste—an herbalist, a graphic artist, a kind of shaman, and, when he is feeding you, definitely a maternal presence.

 He is also extremely handsome, in that way that only Frenchmen can be, fifty-four years old, with a throaty French accent, a widow's peak of black hair, and kind black eyes that have a sexy sparkle. Though he seems calm, he is wont to whip suddenly into those highly focused, intense spurts of energy common to the supremely accomplished. He is not tall, but he is sturdy and emits a gallantry as he stands firmly connected to the ground, taking the stage, as actors put it, with grace and managing, as he looks at you, to maintain a genuine interest in what you are saying.


 On our outing, he was (as befits an eminent New Yorker) wearing all black, and seemed quietly happy to be out and about in Shanghai and in the role of the fed rather than the feeder.


 At the eastern end of Xiangyang Road, chef Ma Jingwei, a man in his early forties, stood outside the Lucky Business Restaurant before a black iron cylinder, much like an oil drum, that was fitted with a flat black iron top which served as the griddle. He was cooking, and the scene was festive. Next to him was a makeshift table; a few boxes with a big metal pan balanced on top, which contained neat rows of browned buns, each about four inches in diameter; and some metal vases holding foot-long breads that looked like elongated doughnuts. A few workmen waited impatiently in line. A woman standing by a cart filled with green melons sang out her wares to passersby: "Melons. Ripe from the country. Melons."


Ma was making Jean-Georges's favorite street food, _jian bing_, a kind of pancake. "It reminds me of France," Jean-Georges murmured. "You know—crêpes. But it's made with rice flour. It's so good." Working at top speed, Ma scooped up some batter and poured it sparingly on the griddle. Then he broke an egg onto the hardening batter and swirled it around. He sprinkled the egg with chopped scallions and a dollop of chili sauce, then deftly shoved the egg under the cooked, wafer-thin pancake, half folding it like origami. Ma then reached behind himself and retrieved a _you tiao_ (baguette-shaped fried dough) and placed it on top of the folded pancake. Another scoop of sauce, more folding, and he cut it in half.

 It was eggy and soft, with the fried waffle, which was salty, adding a wonderful crunchiness. The chili sauce added just a touch of heat. Jean-Georges told me that this _jian bing_ was the street food that inspired him. "I tried to do it, but I couldn't," he said ruefully. "I couldn't figure it out. There are five elements to it, and it must have a flat stove. You can't make it in a pan. I couldn't get the balance." He looked as if he were listening to the taste.


Behind chef Ma, his assistant—a young man in a chef's cap—told me that he had come to Shanghai from a poor province. He wasn't much interested in cooking, but he was interested in having a job, and so he worked from 2 a.m. to 10 a.m. every day frying _you tiao_, which are crispy on the outside and popover-ish on the inside, and browning the round _shao bing_ buns. "I use more than two hundred pounds of flour every day," said Ma proudly, cooking so fast that he seemed to defy gravity. His customers shifted from side to side and talked loudly. At the edge of the sidewalk, an old man shuffled by, taking his black songbird in a square wooden cage for a morning stroll.

[#image: /photos/53ea88ccdd4d6a0b75ef6cbc]|||Chow main: Try xiao long bao (a.k.a. soup dumplings) at Nanxiang Dumpling House, on Yuyam Street.|||

 Ma rents the Lucky Business only in the mornings. When he leaves at 11 a.m., the restaurant reverts to its proprietor, chef Wang Yeda, who also owns the Peace Harmony Dim Sum restaurant next door. Wang is renowned throughout the Concession for his dumplings. At lunchtime, lines of white-shirted office workers stretch out into the street, and delivery boys rush to and fro with little white boxes of his delicious _xiao long bao_, Shanghai's signature soup-filled dumpling. You can get these dumplings all over the city, so I asked him what made his so special. Wang sat down at the one table in his tiny establishment, which has a kitchen that is about four feet by six feet and can barely fit two people. The place is grim and barren, and the floor is so sticky from frying oil that your feet adhere to it. One grimy little window at the back looks out on ragged undershirts hanging from bamboo poles. But the aura is bright and busy. "My soup is more original, and it's the ratio of pork to dumpling skin to broth that's important," he confided. "The balance. Some pork is not as good, or there is too much sugar or too much MSG."


 I had heard about the MSG problem. "It is a world raised on MSG,"said a New York chef who was traveling with Jean-Georges. "So a lightly salted dish tastes very bland to the people here." I asked Jean-Georges if there was any difference cooking for a Chinese clientele. "Oh, yes," he told me, "they are so discerning. Very picky eaters. They are used to everything so fresh. In New York, the fishing boat comes once a week and we buy, but here, a day-old fish is unacceptable."


 Wang's _xiao long bao_ were much better than the other soup dumplings I have had. The skin was thinner and more delicate, the pork mixture more toasty, the soup divine. His head chef stood in the restaurant window, painstakingly pinching the ends of hundreds of little white pork pockets and setting them down in round rattan steamer baskets about two feet wide, as a crowd of onlookers watched closely and Wang's little son toddled happily around them, crowing. He makes eighty pans of dumplings a day.


The dumplings are eaten with a mild vinegar, Jean-Georges explained. "Otherwise, they would be too fatty. The vinegar adds a sourness. It balances the food." Wang said that it had been an arduous week. Thousands of high schoolers had come to Shanghai for the college exam that is given once a year in China: The fate of each student is determined by this test. The small hotels were filled with parents who would visit Wang's to take dumplings to their studying children. These parents wait outside the test venues for hours—it happens every year.

 Next door to Wang's, chef Tan Zhouqing was stirring a huge drum of soup in the window of the Beautiful New Eating Store. Her restaurant serves _ma la tang_, a kind of spicy soup. The excitement here is that you can pick what goes into your soup yourself. Along the back wall is a stand with little baskets of mushrooms, parsley, cabbage, and spinach, and you take what you want and she stirs it into the soup. Attached to the drum are five little bowls, each filled with a different soup seasoning. You choose that too.


Earlier in the week, I had accompanied Jean-Georges to Cao An—the Putuo district's astounding wholesale vegetable market, the biggest in Shanghai. Aircraft hangars filled with vegetables: huge blue bags of soybeans and guava beans; hundreds of green cabbages in red string bags; stacks of carrots, black mushrooms, morels; straw mushrooms in bunches as far as the horizon; cavernous caves of dark-green spinach; long avenues of gnarled, twisted squash in ochers and purples.

 There are hundreds of Chinese vegetables. My housekeeper cooks Shanghai food for me four nights a week. In a year, she never makes the same vegetable twice. Jean-Georges stopped short in the asparagus section. "Amazing!" he said ecstatically. "I want it!"


 He bought several bunches of asparagus, very focused now on a new dish he was concocting.


 "Come," he beckoned to me, and I followed as he hurried into a vast room. "Gingerville!" he cried. And it was. Five-foot-high arrangements of gingerroot, with huge 1930s electric fans, facedown in the center, whirring to keep away mold. "Looks like it should be under the sea, no?" he asked as he picked out some roots and paid for them.


 Jean-Georges told me that his childhood bedroom in Alsace-Lorraine was over the kitchen. "All these smells coming up...," he recalled. "I was influenced." His parents owned a business, and they would cook lunch for their employees. And something of that homey touch remains with Jean-Georges, who insisted that I have lunch when I was in his restaurant and fed me his new soup, standing over me expectantly, waiting for my reaction and explaining, "A little asparagus, some guava beans, some Chinese sausage."


Our walk together along Xiangyang Road ended at the corner where there is a window that looks into the kitchen of a bakery, so you can watch the baker icing cakes. She was squirting frostings of all colors—hot pink, deep red, kelly green—out of a makeshift cloth tube with precision, creating craggy mountain peaks or dragons breathing fire. As we hailed a taxi, Jean-Georges, ruminating on the sweets he had just eaten, concluded, "Everything there is rich. But you go home and you have a glass of wine and it's all right."

Some days later, after Jean-Georges had returned to New York, I went back to the food street. At the corner of Changle Road and Xiangyang, a woman held the handlebars of a bicycle cart filled with oranges. Nearby, the widgets man, his cart overflowing with combs and notions, was selling two safety pins to a woman with a live duck in her bicycle basket. Ladies in high heels zoomed by on red motorcycles. Two Buddhist monks were asking people for money on the corner and giving out pictures of the Buddha. In the police kiosk opposite, the officer was having a postprandial nap. There was a commotion at Wang's—couples were jostling to be the first to buy his dumplings. Wang was outside calling out orders, and I greeted him and told him that New York City's most illustrious chef was in awe of his dumplings.

 Wang nodded matter-of-factly. "Well," he said, "if you're a chef, then you know right away."

play.hed: Shanghai Is Your Next Art Destination: Here's Why
play.dek: Many of Shanghai's best art galleries are located right downtown. We asked Rebecca Catching—a Canadian expat who runs Shanghai's OV Gallery—to select some of the city's top galleries for spotting contemporary art.
play.seoTitle: Shanghai Is Your Next Art Destination: Here's Why
play.seoDescription: Many of Shanghai's best art galleries are located right downtown. We asked Rebecca Catching—a Canadian expat who runs Shanghai's OV Gallery—to select some of the city's top galleries for spotting contemporary art.
play.socialTitle: Shanghai Is Your Next Art Destination: Here's Why
play.socialDescription: Many of Shanghai's best art galleries are located right downtown. We asked Rebecca Catching—a Canadian expat who runs Shanghai's OV Gallery—to select some of the city's top galleries for spotting contemporary art.
play.body:
[#image: /photos/53da85c4dcd5888e145b99eb]|||Some of Shanghai's best street art is found on M50's iconic graffiti wall|||

Shanghai's art galleries have had a rough couple of years: In 2011, some 70 artists were evicted from 696 Weihai Road, the artists' colony that was a cornerstone of the city's contemporary art scene. The galleries that have managed to stay open throughout the city, though, have not only survived but also flourished—and many of the best are located right downtown. We asked Rebecca Catching—a Canadian expat who runs Shanghai's OV Gallery—to select some of the city's top studios for spotting contemporary art and up-and-coming talent.





[#image: /photos/53da85c4dcd5888e145b99e9]|||A larger than life sculpture by Zhang Jianhua|||





**[m97 Gallery](http://www.m97gallery.com/ )** m97 Gallery—located in Shanghai's M50 neighborhood, a string of former warehouses turned into studios and galleries—showcases a great selection of photography from both Chinese and foreign photographers. Among them are photojournalists Michael Wolf and Robert van der Hilst, both of whom examine Chinese interiors through their photos.











**[ShanghART](http://www.shanghartgallery.com)** You can’t leave M50 without paying a visit to what Catching calls “the grand-daddy of the art scene,” Lorenz Helbling’s ShanghART, which opened in 1996. “It is the oldest gallery in Shanghai,” Catching says, “and perhaps in China. It works with very serious artists, people who do amazing shows abroad and participate in biennales all around the world.”











[**AroundSpace**](http://www.aroundspace.org) This gallery, run by a husband and wife team, was originally located in the 696 Weihai Road. Its new Bund home continues to showcase avant garde works from young artists both Chinese and foreign.







**[Shanghai Gallery of Art](http://www.shanghaigalleryofart.com/)** Right on the Bund, inside a gorgeous 1914 Neo-Renaissance structure, is the upmarket Shanghai Gallery of Art. Visiting te windowed, loft-like space is its own treat. But the SGA, Catching says, also “tends to do some interesting group and solo shows and works with more established and mid-career artists.”







**[Rockbund Museum of Art](http://www.rockbundartmuseum.org/cn/cn_newsList.asp )** Consider the Rockbund—located on the northern end of the Bund—a cross between a gallery and a museum. The museum's 1932 Art Deco home, which once belonged to the Royal Asiatic Society, hosts rotating exhibitions showcasing the best in Chinese and international artists (past exhibitors include Zhang Huan and Jenny Holzer).The space itself is also charming, especially the simple roof deck with views across the river.










Photos: Sophie Friedman

play.body:
## [The Grand Tour of Asia](/grand-tour-of-asia)

## The Call of the East
[#image: /photos/53dab6466dec627b149fd34c]||||||

I know this sounds like a bit of revisionist history, but really: I was raised to take this trip. Although the European Grand Tour reached its apotheosis in the nineteenth century, it was still being taken well into the twentieth; indeed, when my father was a college student in Munich in the 1960s, some of his acquaintances had just finished their own grand tours (though by that point, one imagines, theirs were lighter on the exploits of Hadrian and heavier on the search for hashish).







 I had always wanted to take the trip myself, but partly because of my natural predilections (some of us are simply drawn to Asia the way others are drawn to, say, Africa), and partly because I grew up in Hawaii—as close as you can possibly get to Asia while remaining part of America—I knew that my grand tour would take place in the East.





The original Grand Tour would generally begin in Belgium or the Netherlands before moving through Paris, Geneva, Spain, Italy, and perhaps Greece. By the trip’s end, these gentlemen would be able to make the sort of cultural connections that tied the Continent together: They’d have seen how Flemish architecture wed with Roman decoration. They’d have seen how Catholicism divorced from Protestantism. They’d have seen how Greek and Roman mythology resonated in Renaissance art. They would have been able to see history not as linear but as something messier, more colorful, with movements bleeding into one another and uniting Europe as a whole.







 And although my grand tour might take place on a different continent, its objectives—and spirit—remain the same: I wanted to trace how Buddhism spread from its homeland in India and saturated the rest of the continent. I wanted to see how flavors, spices, and grains traveled back and forth along the Silk Road and were interpreted by a multitude of cultures’ palates. It’s an old saw to say that a place is a study in extremes, but really, when it comes to extremes, Asia has all the other continents beat: What other country but China can claim to be home to some of the world’s oldest ruins . . . . and its most cutting-edge skyscrapers? Where else but India can you find a $1 billion single-family residence . . . and the largest population of people living in desperate poverty? Here, the ancient nudges against the future every day. What is it like, I wondered, to travel through a place that wears its sweeping mantle of history so lightly and yet so assuredly?







 The answer? Amazing. And exhausting. And, finally, a little sad: There was no way I was going to be able to squeeze every last destination worth seeing into the time I had, and so some places I’d have loved to include had to be left out (Mongolia, South Korea, Malaysia). Instead, [GeoEx](http://www.geoex.com) and I compiled a greatest-hits tour, one in which you would feel most deeply the echoes of the region’s shared religions, cuisines, and beliefs. Each country would illuminate the similarities (and differences) it shared with the country that preceded it. And we wanted to give you access to the iconic moments that only this continent can provide, whether riding an elephant through the northern Thai jungle or letting millions of dollars of raw diamonds slip through your fingers in Jaipur.







 Those of us lucky enough to fall in love with Asia know that it’s an affair that’s as long as it is resonant. As I write this, for example, I’m in my office in Times Square—8,776 miles from Sri Lanka, where my journey began. But in my mind, I’m actually high in the Japanese mountains. It’s 5 a.m., and the air is so cold it seems to crack with frost. Before me is a young Buddhist priest throwing bundle after bundle of cedar sticks into an orange fire. On the sticks, people have written their prayers: for health, for money, for happiness. All the stuff of earthly concerns, in other words. But when their prayers are burned, they turn to ash, reminding us that everything in life is, in fact, ephemeral, and will trail away in plumes of smoke. Of all the things I saw and bought and tasted in Asia, it is this lesson that I treasure the most: In a world where all is, in the end, ash, the only real moments of glory we have are in the moments of experience. Let yours begin.














## [Begin The Grand Tour of Asia](/grand-tour-of-asia)

play.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d87c6dec627b149dba79]|||Sacred Way, Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum|||

As more travelers move away from escorted tours and start exploring China on their own, we’re seeing Shanghai evolve into a base from which to explore a number of coastal cities. One of our favorites: Nanjing. The town was one of China’s very first cities and has been its capital several times (_nan jing _means southern capital; _bei jing_ means northern)—here's what to see:











**Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum**



 More commonly referred to as the Ming Tombs—a sibling of those in Beijing; the pair form a UNESCO World Heritage site—this is the final resting place of the Hongwu Emperor, founder of the Ming Dynasty. Construction took more than 20 years of laboring by some 100,000 workers and 5,000 guards. The mausoleum is set inside a verdant park that makes for a nice break from downtown Nanjing’s concrete expanse. One of the highlights of a visit here is the stroll along the leafy, mile-long Sacred Way, which is lined by 12 pairs of six stone animals who are believed to guard the tomb. Lions, camels, elephants, and horses all make appearances alongside two mythical Chinese creatures, the qilin and the xiezhi.













[#image: /photos/53d9d87c6dec627b149dba7b]|||Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum|||

**Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum**



 Sun Yat-sen was the first president of the Republic of China party; it ruled modern-day China from 1912 to 1949, until the party—by then known as the Kuomintang—was run out by the Communists and retreated to Taiwan. Given that a rift continues to exist today between Mainland China and Taiwan, it’s surprising that Dr. Sun continues to be revered by not only those in Taiwan but also many within Mainland China. Nearly 400 stairs lead up to the mausoleum, but the hike is worth it; the view from the top is sweeping. During the warmer months, when the surrounding gardens are in full bloom, the vistas are particularly lovely.











**Nanjing City Wall**



 When the Japanese invaded Nanjing in 1937, it was this now 600-year-old-wall that they struggled to break through. Today, a long walk across the top of the wall makes for excellent views, particularly of the lakes and the surrounding, contrasting cityscape (though be warned that it can get very hot during the summer). It’s also great place to take kids, because you can rent bikes and there’s plenty of room to run around.  Pair it with a visit to the Memorial of the Nanjing Massacre, where the wall's significance is explained well.











**Nanjing Massacre Memorial Hall**



 It took nearly 50 years for the government to build a memorial to the more than 300,000 victims of the Nanjing Massacre, but the result is an expansive tribute to those who lost their lives during the Japanese invasion. The museum is well laid-out with very moving displays of historical records, videos, and objects that were uncovered following the city’s pillaging. Particularly arresting are the skeletal remains excavated from a former mass burial site. Outside, there is a memorial walkway with footprints from survivors. Museum placards are in English, Chinese, and Japanese; but, as the Museum’s Chinese name translates to “Memorial for compatriots killed in the Nanjing Massacre by Japanese Forces of Aggression,” there are few Japanese tourists here.













[#image: /photos/53d9d87cdcd5888e145a6645]|||Presidential Palace, Nanjing|||

**Presidential Palace**



 It's not much to look at on the outside, but Nanjing’s Presidential Palace is a worthy stop: You can see the rooms exactly as they were when Sun Yat-sen and Chiang Kai-shek sat in them plotting what they believed would be the future of China. The building housed the office of President of the Republic of China until the Kuomintang fled to Taiwan in 1949, following the Communist defeat. Some background knowledge on the Kuomintang vs. the Nationalists and on the Taiping Rebellion is very helpful, as the placards are in Chinese. As with Sun Yat-sen’s mausoleum, it’s interesting that this site—where the fight against China’s current ruling party was planned—is so heavily visited by Mainland Chinese tourists.





 Photographs, from top: Henry Westheim Photography/Alamy (2), Boaz Rottem/Alamy

fields.name: Context Travel
fields.shortBio:
Context is a network of scholars and specialists who design and lead in-depth walking seminars for small groups of intellectually
 curious travelers across a growing number of cultural destinations.
fields.bio: Context is a network of scholars and specialists—in disciplines including archaeology, art history, cuisine, urban planning, history, environmental science, and classics—who, in addition to our normal work as professors and researchers, design and lead in-depth walking seminars for small groups of intellectually curious travelers. The Context vision is to bring together local scholars and specialists with curious travelers to educate and impassion them; to allow them access to places and cultures that might otherwise remain out of site to the casual visitor; to invite them off the tourist track and into the real life of the people, history, and culture that makes these cities, destinations.

featuredShops.shortDescription: A lane house's beautiful courtyard is home to the offline showroom of this online fashion boutique.

featuredShops.name: Huan Long Camera Market
featuredShops.description: Situated just outside the Shanghai Railway station, the Huan Long camera market on the third floor of the mall sells both old and new cameras but it's the second-hand vintage pieces that most people come here for. You can acquire Holgas and rare Leicas from the seventies, plus specialized lenses and even vintage camera cases.
featuredShops.shortDescription: This camera market sells new cameras and hard-to-find, second-hand vintage pieces.

featuredShops.name: Annabel Lee

address.street: 8 Zhongshan Dong Yi Rd., No. 1, Huangpu

featuredShops.description: Annabel Lee sells elegant, hand-embroidered women's fashions, slippers, purses, and household accessories in delicate fabrics and unfussy colors. The Chinese styles and leitmotifs—such as lotus flowers, dragons, and snuff bottles—allude to 19th-century Shanghai backstreets, though the product quality and consumer appeal is unquestionably 21st-century. The store eloquently portrays how traditional Chinese culture was transformed, but not necessarily destroyed, by the introduction of Western culture in the late 19th century. If the Bund is too far flung, check out her second store in more centrally located in Xintiandi.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Come here for embroidered women's clothes and accessories in delicate fabrics and unfussy colors.

featuredShops.name: Younik
featuredShops.description: Younik, in the Renaissance-pillared Bund 18 building, is a polished second-floor boutique selling ready-to-wear clothes by Korean brand Shion by Choichangho and swish jewelry by fellow Koreans Nouveautes and Taean. Look also for the colorful men's cravats by Nouveautes; assorted bags, purses, and accessories by Shanghai Trio; and modern Scandinavian glassware by Swedish duo Barbro Wesslander and Pia Amsell.
featuredShops.shortDescription: This polished second-floor boutique sells ready-to-wear, jewelry, accessories, and housewares.

pinterest.hed: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
pinterest.dek: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here's where to go.
pinterest.seoTitle: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
pinterest.seoDescription: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here’s where to go.
pinterest.socialTitle: Where to Shop in Shanghai Now
pinterest.socialDescription: From local marketplaces to mega malls, Shanghai is among the best shopping cities in the world. Here’s where to go.

items.caption: The must-go marketplace? Yu Yuan Gardens and Bazaar. Although a bit touristy, it's still worth it for its selection of everything from scarves and clothing to jewelry and knick-knacks (218 Anren St, Huangpu, Shanghai, +86 21 6326 0830).

Almost 6 miles from end to end, Nanjing Road tends to be separated into two sections: Nanjing East Road and Nanjing West Road. Here you’ll find small shops and markets selling original jewelry, accessories, and food, as well as storefronts of larger more commonly known brands. From here, you can also visit Reel Mall, on Nanjing West Road, which is full of high end stores from both Chinese and International designers.

Art collectors shouldn’t miss the M50 Art Hub on Morgan Shan Road. The artist-run complex, which houses galleries such as ShanghART (50 Moganshan Rd, Putuo, Shanghai, +86 21 6359 3923, [shanghartgallery.com](http://shanghartgallery.com)) and Art Scene China (2/F, Bldg #4, 50 Morganshan Road, Shanghai, +86 21 6277 4940, [artscenechina.com](http://artscenechina.com)), is worth a visit for anyone interested in China’s contemporary art scene.

Shanghai is well known for its custom tailoring and designs. At W.W. Chan & Sons Tailor Ltd., you’ll be able to construct an entire wardrobe from scratch. You can bring in photographs of styles you’re interested in, and then choose your own fabrics from the voluminous collection of sample books ( 528, 5/F, West Tower Shanghai Centre, 1376 Nanjing Road West, +86 21 6289 8682, [wwchan.com](http://wwchan.com)).

Pearls are a local specialty, and Shanghai Pearl City stocks pearls in every size, shape, and hue. It can be a bit overwhelming, so you need to know what you’re looking for, but their prices are quite competitive so it’s well worth the trip (3721 Hongmei Lu, Shanghai, +86 21 6262 3851).

Founded in 2010, M.R.K.T. is full of architecture-inspired bags and accessories in clean, geometric concepts, all made of everything from vegan leather to felt, and produced in a rainbow of colors (741 Julu Rd, Jing'an, Shanghai, +86 21 5403 0791, [mrktstore.com](http://mrktstore.com)).

In addition to her undying passion for this perfect concrete jungle, she lives for the beaches of Cape Cod and ski slopes of Tahoe. A striped shirt aficionado and lover of classic pajama sets, she will forever be on the hunt for the next eclectic bracelet to add to her collection.

pinterest.dek: Food writer and chef Christopher St Cavish shares his top picks for Chinese specialties and dining options in Shanghai.
pinterest.hed: A Chef's Guide to Shanghai Cuisine

items.title: Jia Jia Dumplings
items.caption: Xiao long bao, or “little steamer buns," are Shanghai’s calling card. Also known as soup dumplings, the trick here is that the soup is on the inside. A hundred years after their invention in Nanxiang village, the debate rages on about the merits of a thin skin, the porkiness of the filling, and the time elapsed between being made and eating. These, from Jia Jia Tangbao, win high marks in all categories.

items.title: Jia Jia Steam Girls
items.caption: Although xiao long bao are ubiquitous in Shanghai, small venues that make and steam them to order are not. At Jia Jia Tangbao, a crew of young women (said to be chosen for their nimble fingers, essential in handling the delicate dumplings) fill and wrap the dumplings to order and then must brave the steam to retrieve them several minutes later.

items.title: Yangcheng Lake crabs
items.caption: Crab connoisseurs may already know about Shanghai’s hairy crabs, so-called for a matted flop on their claws and fine golden hairs on their legs. True aficionados, however, head straight to Yangcheng Lake an hour away to pick out their crabs themselves. The show up sometime later trussed, steamed, and ready to dip in mellow brown vinegar.

items.title: Zongzi, wrapped
items.caption: In early summer, these bamboo-leaf wrapped parcels, known as zongzi, start appearing en masse in anticipation of the Dragon Boat Festival. The story goes that after an ancient poet-scholar drowned in a lake, the locals threw rice into the waters to distract the fish.

items.title: Zongzi, unwrapped
items.caption: These days, the locals are much more practical. Instead of drowning perfectly good rice, they season it with soy sauce, push a piece of red-braised pork or a salted egg yolk in the center, and wrap it in bamboo or reed leaves to be steamed—a win for the living. These particular zongzi are the work of Chubby Feng, a suburban Shanghai farmer-turned-zongzi mogul.

items.title: Sheng Jian Bao
items.caption: These shallow-fried dumplings are sheng jian bao, the masculine answer to the feminine xiao long bao. Their thicker wrappers hold a similar pork broth inside, but instead of a gentle steam, they go for a golden crisping in these large, iron pans and a sprinkling of sesame seeds and chopped spring onions. These are only found in Shanghai.

items.title: Hot Pot, Yi Pin Ju
items.caption: Although Shanghainese may position themselves in public as much more sophisticated than those Beijing northerners, they’re not above borrowing their hot pot technique in private. Expensive cars line up outside of hole-in-the-wall Yi Pin Ju, smack in downtown, for its hand-cut Mongolian lamb, which gets swished around the coal-fired brass pot and then dunked in a sauce of sesame paste, coriander, and soy sauce or vinegar.

items.title: Liangfen, Yu Xin
items.caption: Sichuan’s fiery cuisine has spread across China in the last decade, and it's extremely popular in Shanghai. Yu Xin Chuan Cai, a chain that originated in Chongqing and cooks as if it never left, is one of the best. Here, the chuanbei liangfen, a cool noodle made from beans, slathered in a spicy, garlicky, and deep savory chili sauce.

items.title: Night Market, Old Town
items.caption: Scenes like this nighttime, al fresco kitchen are disappearing in Shanghai but can still be found on a number of streets in Nanshi, the Old Town of dense, low-rise buildings and lively alleys that is under threat from the march of the skyscrapers.  Even at 3 a.m., as this photo shows, these quick and dirty stir-fry joints do a brisk trade.

items.title: North Korean
items.caption: For something a bit different, try one of Shanghai’s several North Korean restaurants. The NK government-owned chain [Pyongyang Okryu](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/02/north-korean-restaurant-amsterdam-europe-pyongyang) serves up a song and dance along with its banchan and grilled short ribs, complete with North Korean waitresses in traditional dress playing guitars and drums, or belting out folk ballads.

pinterest.hed: What's For Dinner at Shanghai Hot Spot Liquid Laundry
pinterest.dek: Drawing on their experience running one of [China’s first microbreweries](http://www.boxingcatbrewery.com/), Kelley Lee and her partner Lee Tseng have turned their attentions to a more grown-up space. At Liquid Laundry, the duo is slinging cocktails and beer, deconstructed desserts, and face bacon, which they promise isn’t as scary as it sounds. Here’s what’s for dinner at Liquid Laundry.

items.caption: Liquid Laundry is restaurateur Kelley Lee’s _Field of Dreams_. “I knew if we built it, people would come,” she explains—and after months of red tape and delays, they have in droves. A 10-year Shanghai veteran, the L.A.-born, Cordon Bleu-trained Lee counts seven venues in her China portfolio, with another due to open later this year. Still, she’s in awe of her new venture’s “fantastic” early reception and chalks it up to the power of social media.

“We wanted to bring to Shanghai something that was very New York: industrial but at the same time a little bit warm,” says Lee Tseng. To do so, they gutted the space—what was once a high-end Cantonese restaurant—and, under the tutelage of Australian architect Hannah Churchill, transformed it into a 7,500-square-foot behemoth combining styles and textures (including mosaic-and-hardwood floors, and subway-tile–lined walls). British designer [Siu Tang](http://www.theorangeblowfish.com/) is the brain behind the bar’s risqué-funny graphics and text, including a coaster that reads, “your clothes look better on my bedroom floor.” The bar itself is stocked with beers brewed in-house, seven from Lee and Tseng’s brewery, Boxing Cat, and rotating drafts from European and American brewers. Craft cocktails come via Warren Peng of [Beijing bar Janes & Hooch](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/06/photos-best-new-bars-clubs-2013).

items.title: Hannibal Lecter Special
items.caption: “Our chef, Sean Jorgensen, learned how to make face bacon when we were in New York for StarChefs Congress, and he decided he wanted this dish to be at the restaurant,” says Lee. “We made it, but we found that the pork heads in China were much fattier than the pork heads that were being used in the US. There was less meat in the jowls and other parts of the face. Once we cooked it, it wasn’t holding together very well, so it couldn’t be sliced and put on a plate nicely. We pan-fried a little bit of it, and I had some bread sitting around, so I put it together. It was delicious! We thought the name was hilarious. It’s much harder to sell people face bacon than it is to put a name on it that’s funny, and people would order it—and they do.”

items.title: Beer Braised Beef Tongue Sliders
items.caption: “We braise the beef tongue, throw that on top of our ground beef patties, and then, to cut the richness of the beef tongue, pair it with horseradish aioli and pickled carrots and onions,” explains Lee. “I felt that we couldn’t just serve beef tongue sliders without the patty, because beef tongue is a bit of a hard sell, even in Shanghai. What I thought we had to do was kind of sneak it into a dish that people are used to eating, like a slider. It’s turned out to be very popular.”

items.title: Compressed Watermelon Salad
items.caption: “It’s a simple and fresh summer salad, one of our lightest dishes, and the watermelon keeps it cool. We have some salads on the menu because man cannot live by beef tongue and pork trotter alone…I suppose, although I probably could. Sean Jorgensen and I are always working on menu items; when something is pretty and has flowers, people think it’s mine, but when it’s made of meat or it’s fatty, they think that must be Sean’s—which is not true.”

items.title: Crispy Fried Pork Trotters
items.caption: “Pork trotter can be a difficult sell because it’s an off cut, but local customers _love_ them! We cook it down until it’s very soft, then we press it into squares, bread it, crisp it, and then we serve it with pickled red onions and a sauce gribiche which gives it nice taste contrast. And of course, we make them pretty by dressing the plate with flowers—what are we going to do in winter?”

items.title: Crack Pizza
items.caption: “It’s one of our top-selling pizzas, but I think that people just love the name—_crack_. It goes into the oven for three minutes at 380°C [approximately 715°F] and it’s done. We were playing with the dough for three weeks straight and the pizzas were the bane of my existence. I tasted five different doughs a day and thought, I never want to look at another pizza again. And how did we get our two-ton pizza oven into our second-floor space? It was a rough day. They hooked up winches, hoisted this huge pizza oven up on straps, swung it over our granite bar counter, and then one strap broke. One of the workers had the weight on his back for 20 minutes…and he had a cigarette the whole time!”

items.title: Seared Yellowtail
items.caption: “This is another one of our lighter, refreshing dishes. We marinate the fish Japanese style—first putting it into sugar to rest for 40–50 minutes, taking it out, putting it in salt for 40 minutes, and then washing it with a mixture of rice wine and sake. We rest for another half hour, take it out, and then sear it. We top the slices with roast pumpkin, puffed black rice, Asian pear, pine nuts, avocado, and slivers of pickled ginger in a sesame-Asian pear dressing, which gives it a nice little kick.”

items.title: Sausage of the week
items.caption: “We wanted to call it Sean’s Italian Sausage but…eh. This week, we’re making hot Italian sausage, which we like to write in bold on the blackboard. It’s served with a bacon chanterelle hash. Depending on how fast it sells, we could change out the sausage three times a week. The last one that we had was the _morcilla_; I couldn’t call it blood sausage because then no one would order it, but when I called it morcilla it sold super well. Everyone knows these things are delicious, but people may have hang-ups about food. We’re trying to push the boundaries a bit and get people to eat things they normally wouldn’t. We make all our sausage in-house—the pork meat in China is quite good.”

items.title: Laundry’s Strawberry Shortcake
items.caption: “We decided to make this because it’s strawberry season in Shanghai. I love how the textures all go together—sweet, tart, creamy, and soft. Most of our desserts have some element of sorbet or ice cream, which made it difficult when our imported ice cream maker did _not_ arrive on time. Luckily, I have this refillable liquid nitrogen card, and when I found it, I went and had the tanks refilled. I had to explain to our driver in broken Chinese what it was he was going to be driving around and how he had to open the windows and secure the tanks so that they wouldn’t tip over and asphyxiate him when he was driving! I don’t think he felt at ease. Once that hassle was over, we got the nitrogen into the restaurant and we’ve been making ice cream since. And now we’ve finally received our ice cream maker!”

pinterest.hed: What to Do in Shanghai: An Insider's Guide
pinterest.dek: Yilei Wu is the CEO and co-founder of [Xinlelu.com](http://www.xinlelu.com/)—once only ecommerce, but now happily a Shanghai brick-and-mortar store as well. Born and raised in Shanghai, she sat down with __Condé Nast Traveler__ to tell us about her love of the city and what you can’t miss when you visit.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/54762ad12a3d21fa285caba8]|||
Yilei at her studio. 
|||





[Yilei](https://cntraveler.com/shops/shanghai/xinlelu-com-showroom) is from a fashion marketing and journalism background, originally coming to the store from a design angle. Meeting Jillian Xin, who has a background in finance, they found that there was so much they could do together to develop the business and inspire one another. Yilei credits the diversity and creativity of the city with the growing industry of entrepreneurs and creative industries.


[#image: /photos/5480eddd860c74c1162c6c5f]|||
The Xinlelu boutique; Yilei with friend Elsa.
|||





Part of what makes Xinlelu unique is it’s vast and eclectic collection of indie designers from all over the world. In charge of buying, Yilei sources labels from international trade shows as well as designers through word-of-mouth and industry support. She feels, as big as the city is, the creative circle remains close.

Whether local designers, or those based far away, almost all designers represented in the store come from an international background, which is important because they are knowledgable both about different cultures and western retail systems as well as Chinese culture and customs. 

Yilei aims to redefine the slowly changing vision of Shanghai style and culture as quite sophisticated and carrying an air of exclusivity. Through bits of twists in design and quirky elements that she sources in her designers, the store’s collection balances between classic culture and young modernity.

##Yilei's Shanghai Picks


[#image: /photos/5480ede0b6e03e8c2d0c9e7f]|||
Yours Concept Store; Yilei's studio mascot. 
|||







##Ju Lu Lu/Fu Min Lu
When not in her own store, her favorite area to shop is Ju Lu Lu/Fu Min Lu. Walking around, she suggests stops at Absolute Florist, Yours Concept Store, and Yaci Ceramics. Additionally, Industrial menswear boutique and [Backroom](http://www.weibo.com/thebackroom) lifestyle boutique rank among favorites.

##JingAn Villa
Slightly off the beaten path, Yilei suggests a trip to JingAn Villa, where the Xinlelu studio is, among other similar ventures. The walk through the small, creative agencies similar to her own provides a much more relaxing and cozy community.

##[Dreams Flea Market](http://dreamsfleamarket.taobao.com/)
Another not-to-miss is Dreams Flea Market. Time it correctly, for it’s only open once a month, but they target local young women and men, providing a lively vibe with awesome finds at good bargains. Creators Sisi Yu and Ken Goh bring together a collection of vintage items and unique artistic creations alike.

##[Subconscious Spa](http://www.subconsciousdayspa.com/home/)
For a true indulgence (or perhaps between shopping excursions!) head to Subconscious Spa on Ju Lu Lu, another favorite of Yilei. With services ranging from a massage or facial to a manicure or even yoga class, you are sure to find a way to unwind during your travels.

related.hed: The One Dish To Eat in Shanghai
related.dek: Paul Pairet, the chef behind the buzzy high-concept Shanghai restaurant Ultraviolet on his favorite dish-including where and how to eat it.
related.seoTitle: The One Dish To Eat in Shanghai
related.seoDescription: Paul Pairet, the chef behind the buzzy high-concept Shanghai restaurant Ultraviolet on his favorite dish-including where and how to eat it.
related.socialTitle: The One Dish To Eat in Shanghai
related.socialDescription: Paul Pairet, the chef behind the buzzy high-concept Shanghai restaurant Ultraviolet on his favorite dish-including where and how to eat it.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/549480d31d0dfc7664103ac6]||||||





__You can't leave Shanghai without eating…__

Xiao long bao (Chinese soup dumplings). “This may not be the most surprising recommendation to someone who lives in Shanghai,” says Pairet, “but there’s a reason these dumplings are the city’s signature dish. I, and most people I know, crave them constantly.” There are many different schools of thought about what makes xiao long bao so addictive but, Pairet says, the difference between an average bowl and a melt-in-your-mouth one comes down to three things. First, the wonton wrapper must be thin enough to give the dumpling a satisfyingly explosive bite but also strong enough to withstand the piping hot soup it contains. Second, the stuffing, usually a seasoned mixture of pork and gelatin, must be fatty enough to melt in your mouth. And third, the soup must be rich with flavor.

__How to eat it:__ “I don’t know why, but xiao long bao are always burning, burning hot,” Pairet warns. The traditional solution is to break open the top of each dumpling and let it breathe before dipping it in vinegar then eating it. 

__Where to eat it:__ While there are many higher-end options in Shanghai, Pairet recommends Crystal Jade. The restaurant’s neighborhood, Xintiandi, is well-touristed, and it’s part of a local Cantonese chain. But of all Shanghai’s dumpling spots, Crystal Jade wins—consistently--in each of the three categories (wonton, stuffing, and soup). 

__The science:__ Food writer Christopher St. Cavish, Pairet’s former sous chef at Ultraviolet, is currently working on the final stages of his “Shanghai Soup Dumpling Index”—an attempt to create an objective list of the 20 best xiao long bao restaurants in the city. St. Cavish went to extreme lengths, including measuring wrapper thickness with calipers, to determine which eateries would place on his list. And while the results aren’t yet in, the popular dumpling restaurant Jia Jia Tangbao has previously topped the writer’s list of xiao long bao haunts.
