related.hed: Michael Kors’s 5-Step Guide to Conquering Shanghai
related.dek: Michael Kors is the latest designer to open up shop in Shanghai, the world’s new shopping capital. We asked him for his tips on seeing the city in style.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/5473b235cbbd2620680dcfa4]|||
Kors and co. cutting the tape at the grand opening of his new Shanghai store.
|||  


##Stop by the Flagship
The exterior of the [Michael Kors store in Shanghai](http://cntraveler.com/shops/shanghai/michael-kors-shanghai) (currently the largest Kors outpost in the world) was inspired by a sequined gown. It’s located in Shanghai's [Jing'an Kerry Centre](http://www.jingankerrycentre.com/), a luxury shopping center spread over three towers on Nanjing Road West. (*1618 Nanjing Road West, Jing’an District, Shanghai, +86 21 6288 7128*)


##Fly Direct 
 When traveling to Shanghai, Kors always flies direct. Travel essentials include Beats by Dre Headphones, an iPad, La Mer lip balm, and a cozy cashmere sweater.

##Go Modern 
Upon arrival, Kors heads to either the [Peninsula Hotel](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/marana/peninsula-shanghai) or [Park Hyatt](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/china/shanghai/park-hyatt-shanghai*). He loves the former for its Art Deco luxe, and the latter for its dazzling views over the Bund (it’s the tallest hotel in the world). First stop at the Park Hyatt? A swim in its pool on the 85th floor.

##Find the Cashmere and Silk 
Kors doesn’t leave Shanghai without stocking up on cashmere wraps from Ruyee Life Gallery on the Bund (*1 Lane 8, Zhong Shan Dong Yi Lu, Shanghai, +86 21 6445 8218*) and then heads to Shiatzy Chen for silk and cotton pieces (*32 The Bund, Zhongshan Dong Yi Road, Shanghai, +86 21 6321 9155, shiatzychen.com*).

##Don't Leave without tasting Dim Sum
No trip to China is complete without a dim sum stop. Kors recommends the Kerry Center outpost of popular dumpling restaurant Din Tai Fung, whose signature dumpling is, of course, the traditional soup dumpling (*2F, Yu Fashion Garden, 168 Fangbang M. Road, Shanghai, +86  21 6334 1008, dintaifungusa.com*).

related.body:
The hotel is spectacular, sure. But what about life outside its doors? Here are the places to go and things to see in...


## Copenhagen

[#image: /photos/53daa5d06dec627b149f8cce]||||||

**You have two hours before you can check in:**







A five-minute bus ride on the way into town from the airport, the silvery [Den Blå Planet aquarium](http://www.denblaaplanet.dk/en/) resembles some of the sea creatures it contains. Watching leopard sharks and rays cruise around their plush digs is a soothing post-red-eye activity, and there's a good café if you need coffee _(Jacob Fortlingsvej 1)._







**You want to eat five minutes from your hotel:**



For reasonably priced, authentic Nordic food—salted cod, salmon, open sandwiches—in a canteen-style setting from Claus Meyer, the man who helped make Noma maestro René Redzepi a legend, visit [Meyers Deli](http://www.meyersdeli.dk/) in the basement of Magasin du Nord _(Kongens Nytorv 13; entrées from $12)._











**You want to sneak in one more thing before you go home:**







If you've already shopped at [HAY](http://hay.dk/) _(Pilestraede 29-31)_ and [Illums Bolghius](http://www.illumsbolighus.com/) _(Amagertorv 10)_ and you're still hungry for Danish design, head to Copenhagen ceramist Anne Black's concept store in Frederiksberg to snag her wafer-thin, hand-luggage-friendly porcelain pieces _(Gammel Kongevej 105)_.










## Lima

[#image: /photos/53daa5d06dec627b149f8cd0]|||Tostaduria Bisetti|||

**You have two hours before you can check in:**



Photographer Mario Testino has become the face of contemporary Peruvian art, and [MATE](http://www.mate.pe/), his nonprofit organization and gallery, champions the work of regional artists and shows images from Testino's own archive _(Av. Pedro de Osma 409; 51-1-251-7755)_. Follow a visit with a cup of homegrown coffee at nearby Barranco institution [Tostaduria Bisetti](http://www.cafebisetti.com/) _(Av. Pedro de Osma 116)_.







**You want to eat five minutes from your hotel:**







It may be a more a five-minute drive than a five-minute walk, but head to the neighboring district of Miraflores for a meal at the buzzy [Central Restaurante](http://centralrestaurante.com.pe/en/). Chef Virgilio Martinez seasons his unusual indigenous ingredients (try _arracacha_, a root vegetable from the Andes, or _paiche_, an Amazonian fish) with herbs picked from the restaurant's garden _(Calle Santa Isabel 376; 51-1-242-8515; entrées from $21)_.







**You want to sneak in one more thing before you go home:**







[MAC Lima](http://www.maclima.pe/), the city's long-awaited contemporary art museum, is perfect for a quick, colorful hit of Latin American pop art _(Av. Miguel Grau 1511; 51-1-514-6800)_.










## Shanghai

[#image: /photos/53daa5d0dcd5888e145c27bc]|||The Oriental Pearl|||

**You have two hours before you check in:**







Whether you love or hate the [Oriental Pearl](http://www.opg.cn/), a radio and TV tower built in 1994, the 360-degree views of the city from the observation floor will give you a quick and impressive perspective on the layout of Shanghai. Afterward, head to the adjoining Pudong Riverside Promenade for a jet lag-lifting stroll.







**You want to eat five minutes from your hotel:**







Don't be fooled by the name: [The Bellagio](http://www.bellagiocafe.com.cn/) in the DBS Bank Tower serves delicious Taiwanese cuisine, like shrimp in crullers (which resembles a fried noodle taco) and dragon bean stir-fry, at reasonable prices _(B1/F, DBS Bank Tower, 1223 Lujiazui Huan Lu; entrées from $13)_.







**You want to sneak in one more thing before you go home:**







Head to treasure trove **Annata Vintage**, where tea dresses, retro handbags, and 1920s Mary Janes have been handpicked from markets all over the world. The complimentary coffee and the sweet service contribute to the pleasant experience _(No 23, 316 Jianguo Xi Lu, Xuhui District)_.

related.hed: China's Newest Wacky Attraction Is This House
related.dek: This strange attraction is only the latest in a long line of weird architecture in China.
related.seoTitle: China's Newest Wacky Attraction Is This House
related.seoDescription: This strange attraction is only the latest in a long line of weird architecture in China.
related.socialTitle: China's Newest Wacky Attraction Is This House
related.socialDescription: This strange attraction is only the latest in a long line of weird architecture in China.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/53da9fa66dec627b149f77fe]||||||

An upside down gablefront is the latest architectural anomaly out of China, where stunt buildings and post-modern construction have rapidly become national pastimes. The new upside down house is just one of the attractions at Fengjing Ancient Town, known for its many canals and artful stone bridges and a popular day trip about an hour from downtown Shanghai. The house is scheduled to open in April, when its interiors—also upside down—will also be finished.



Elsewhere in China, visitors can find [replicas of the Eiffel Tower](http://www.nbcnews.com/news/photo/eiffel-tower-replica-looms-over-chinas-parisian-style-ghost-town-v19838089), [a replica village inspired by England's country towns](http://behindthewall.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/07/13/12725483-the-ghosts-that-haunt-chinas-economic-landscape?lite), [a duplicate Venice](http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/original-copies-architectural-mimicry-in-contemporary-china), and even bizarre theme parks, like the questionable "Dwarf's Empire," where [little people are the main attraction](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/titanic-replica-bad-theme-park-ideas).



The knock offs are so common across the country they inspired a book, _Original Copies: Architectural Mimicry in Contemporary China_. In it, author Bianca Bosker "explores what this unprecedented experiment in 'duplitecture' implies for the social, political, architectural, and commercial landscape of contemporary China." It's a bit academic—[as befits a volume published by a university press](http://www.uhpress.hawaii.edu/p-8759-9780824836061.aspx)—but Bosker does illuminate why it is that these fakes keep popping up. As she explained in [an interview about the book with the website Atlas Obscura](http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/original-copies-architectural-mimicry-in-contemporary-china) last year, "China, at least traditionally, has viewed copying with far greater nuance and tolerance than we have in the West. This perspective has helped create a copy-friendly climate where knockoff White Houses and Monet-manufacturing centers can flourish." The projects also pave a path to the future, [Bosker says in the same interview](http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/original-copies-architectural-mimicry-in-contemporary-china):







"China’s current government leaders are also strategically encouraging imitation across a number of fields as a way for China to gain a competitive edge. In 2001, for example, the Shanghai government decided to hire ten foreign firms to build ten themed cities around Shanghai, each built in the style of a different European country. The officials in charge of the project noted they hoped working with foreign architects would help domestic designers come away with a sharper skill set they could apply to helping the nation grow and urbanize."





This house, it seems, is just the latest step forward.

fields.name: Paul Brady
fields.shortBio: Paul Brady is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s consumer news editor.
fields.bio: Paul Brady is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s consumer news editor, with a focus on the strategies that help consumers have better trips. He has been covering the travel industry for nearly 10 years, at *Condé Nast Traveler*, The Huffington Post, *Budget Travel*, and other outlets. He graduated from the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University.

miniGuides.dek: Shanghai is spliced by the Huangpu River, which divides the older districts of Puxi, on the west bank, from high-rise Pudong on the east bank, whose soaring, modern architectural statements are testaments to China’s grand economic ambitions. If you have just a few hours in Shanghai, base yourself in Puxi, which provides a livelier and more personal experience.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548b4a7cb6e03e8c2d0cc08a]|||See the city from a vintage motorbike courtesy of a tour with Shanghai Insiders.|||



##EAT HERE
   
At 


[#restaurant: /restaurants/53eae4be976f8f2d44d58615]|||
Lost Heaven
|||



, order one of the spice-infused dishes inspired by the ethnic cuisines found along the ancient tea-trade route that ran through southern China’s Yunnan province into Southeast Asia. Candlelit crimson interiors and Tibetan-attired servers add to the ambiance. Or head to 


[#restaurant: /restaurants/53eae4c2976f8f2d44d58625]|||
Ultraviolet
|||



, Shanghai’s most unique dining experience. (Just be sure to reserve well ahead—heck, plan your trip around it.) Ultraviolet is a 10-seat restaurant in a secret location (they deliver you there by car) presenting a 20-course avant-garde set dinner accompanied by its own taste-enhancing choreography of sounds, scents, and video projections.


##PLAY HERE
  


[#activity: /activities/5475ea67f3cd9c7947d67820]|||
Shanghai Insiders
|||



 is a way to explore Shanghai is in the sidecar of a repro Changjiang motorcycle (the vintage bikes were used by China’s People’s Liberation Army until the 1990s). Tours are fully customizable and the drivers double as savvy city guides. 


##SHOP HERE 
Spin Ceramic's gallery-like store showcases contemporary ceramic tableware and accessories crafted in the imperial kiln city of Jingdezhen. You’ll want it all—and they’ll even ship overseas if you don’t have enough suitcase space.
miniGuides.seoTitle: How to Spend the Perfect Day in Shanghai
miniGuides.seoDescription: If you have just three hours in Shanghai, base yourself in Puxi, which provides a lively and more authentic Shanghai experience.

fields.name: Amy Fabris-Shi
fields.shortBio: Sydney-born, Shanghai-based travel writer reporting on all things chic in China
fields.bio: Sydney-born Amy Fabris-Shi toured the world as a professional ballerina but now takes a rather more leisurely approach to travel as a globetrotting writer and co-founder of boutique content consultancy, [Scribes of the Orient](www.scibesoftheorient.com). Based in Shanghai for the past decade, she writes about all things chic in China and beyond for publications including *Elite Traveler*, *Conde Nast Traveller* and *MO Magazine*.

miniGuides.dek: Shanghai was carved into foreign-run concessions following the 1840-42 Sino-British Opium War; you can still find evidence of those historic influences in the architecture and attitude of its downtown neighborhoods. From the grandiose British-built mansions along the riverfront Bund, to the leafy avenues, boutiques and boulangeries of the former French Concession, the city is an often-electic mix of past and future, tradition and innovation.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548b4a7c860c74c1162c8f4c]||||||







##Day 1  
__The Neighborhood: The Bund__. Shanghai’s iconic postcard vista, this one-mile row of stately Neoclassical, Baroque, and Art Deco stone buildings fronting the riverbank were once international banks and British trading houses. Today, the former Wall Street of China is home to the city’s sleekest restaurants, clubs, art galleries and boutiques.

__STAY__  


[#hotel: /hotels/53dacbb0dcd5888e145cdadb]|||
The Peninsula Shanghai
|||



: At the northern edge of the Bund, with spectacular views along the Huangpu riverfront, The Peninsula is a paean to Shanghai’s decadent 1930s with mod-Deco interiors, jazz-serenaded high teas, and a luxury yacht for rock star-worthy river cruising.

__EAT__  


[#restaurant: /restaurants/53eae4bf976f8f2d44d58619]|||
Mr. & Mrs. Bund
|||



: A Bund-front dining room serving up French chef Paul Pairet’s award-winning take on brasserie fare, with lots of creative twists. For dessert, order the lemon tart, which is served as a whole lemon, skin and all. 


__SHOP__  


[#shop: /shops/5474fa76f3cd9c7947d672c4]|||
Suzhou Cobblers
|||



: Inspired by her grandmother’s collection of classic Chinese slippers, local designer Denise Huang creates handcrafted silk slip-ons and shoes embroidered with stylish Oriental motifs, from peonies to pompoms. Check out her latest designs at her jewelbox-like boutique just off the Bund. 

__SEE__  


[#activity: /activities/5474fb3315fa044b14f34c25]|||
Rockbund Art Museum (RAM)
|||



: One block behind the Bund, RAM hosts some of Shanghai’s more edgily curated contemporary art exhibits in a 1933 Art Deco building restored by British architect David Chipperfield. 


[#image: /photos/548b4a76b6e03e8c2d0cc06c]||||||





##Day 2  
__The Neighborhood: Former French Concession__. This charming borough, distinguished by its tree-lined avenues of 90-year-old platane trees imported from Paris, is filled with lively residential alleys and European-style garden villas converted into chic boutiques, cafes, and cocktail lounges. Grab a fresh croissant and go for a stroll along the elegant boulevards and into the lively residential lanes, known as *longtang.*

__STAY__
   


[#hotel: /hotels/5474fc2f8303ec8a4b552a4d]|||
Mansion Hotel 
|||



: A plush 32-room boutique residence in a 1930s manor built by a notorious Shanghai mob boss. Suites come with private stone terraces overlooking the heritage domes of the 1932 Russian Orthodox Church. 

__EAT__   


[#restaurant: /restaurants/5474fd2a15fa044b14f34c2a]|||
Sichuan Citizen
|||



: This place is hot – and not just because of its chili-laced menu and red-hued dining room. Book ahead or be prepared to wait at the bar. Temper the peppery Sichuan heat with the house specialty: the cooling basil drop martinis. 


[#bar: /bars/53eae5bf976f8f2d44d58b8f]|||
Yongfoo Elite
|||



: Step into a Chinoiserie fantasy at this gorgeous club restaurant and lounge in the former British Consulate villa. A drink on the opium bed beneath the lantern-strung magnolia tree is truly transporting. 

__SHOP__  


[#shop: /shops/53eae52b976f8f2d44d58883]|||
Song Fang Maison de Thé
|||



: A tea salon and boutique in a traditional lanehouse selling handpicked Chinese and French teas. Packaged in stylish aquamarine tins with Chinese propaganda images, they make chic Shanghai souvenirs.


[#shop: /shops/5474ffd7f3cd9c7947d6736b]|||
Shokay
|||



: This Shanghai-based socially responsible label creates stylish-and-sustainable accessories spun from Tibetan yak down, which is as soft as the finest cashmere. Pieces are hand-knitted by a women’s cooperative on Chongming Island near Shanghai.

__SEE__   


[#activity: /activities/547500a18303ec8a4b552aac]|||
Propaganda Poster Art Centre
|||



: This small but stimulating museum hidden in the basement of a nondescript apartment block showcases a vast private collection of Mao-era Communist revolutionary propaganda artworks charting almost 20 years of turbulent post-War Chinese history. 


[#shop: /shops/53eae52cdd4d6a0b75efc552]|||
Tianzifang
|||



: Get lost in the labyrinth of grey-brick alleys filled with boutiques and cafes housed in former shikumen (stone-gated) homes. Kommune Café is a pleasant spot for coffee in its sun-dappled courtyard. 


[#image: /photos/548b4a76860c74c1162c8f2e]||||||





##Day 3  
__The Neighborhood: Hongkou District__. For something a little off-the-tourist trail, venture across the century-old Garden Bridge over Suzhou Creek to the Hongkou district. This area marked the American (and, later, Japanese) settlements prior to 1949. Until recently, Hongkou had been spared the hectic modernization visited upon other parts of the city, and here you can still find hidden architectural gems and authentic Shanghainese street culture. 

__STAY__  


[#hotel: /hotels/54750237f3cd9c7947d6737b]|||
Astor House Hotel 
|||



: Shanghai’s oldest remaining hotel has operated on this site since 1858, although the current English Renaissance building with its fabulously creaky wood-floored halls dates from 1911. While it's a little faded around the edges, the history and reasonable rates are hard to beat. 

__EAT__  


[#bar: /bars/53eae5bedd4d6a0b75efc8ba]|||
Vue Restaurant & Lounge
|||



: Vue, which crowns Hyatt on the Bund hotel, is named after its finest asset – a spine-tingling terrace vista overlooking a bend in the Huangpu River and encompassing both the heritage Bund and futuristic Pudong skylines on opposing banks. 

__SHOP__  


[#activity: /activities/5475044ff3cd9c7947d67390]|||
Chai Living Gallery & Lounge
|||



 & Lounge: Housed in the 1935 Embankment Building – once the largest apartment building in the Far East – Spanish artist Tucho’s gorgeous gallery presents a covetable collection of contemporary artworks and antiques collected on his travels. There’s also a cute little cafe. 

__SEE__  


[#activity: /activities/5475064af3cd9c7947d673a6]|||
1933 
|||



: In Shanghai’s 1930s heyday, even its abattoir was an Art Deco gem. This unique architectural icon is now home to design studios and pop-up markets.
